conclusion: Consider the electric field due to the two point charges at points M and N.
Electric field due to a point charge Q at distance r is E = kQ/r^2.
At point B, distances to charges +Q at M and -Q at N are both L.
Electric field due to +Q at M is E_M = kQ/L^2.
Electric field due to -Q at N is E_N = kQ/L^2.
Field E_M points away from M towards B; field E_N points towards N from B.
M, N, and B form an equilateral triangle, angle between fields is 60 degrees.
Horizontal components of E_M and E_N cancel each other out.
Vertical components add up: E_vertical = E_M sin(60) + E_N sin(60).
Electric force F on the ball is F = qE.
Substitute vertical component of electric field: F = q(kQsqrt(3)/L^2).
Magnitude of electric force experienced by the small ball at point B is F = kqQsqrt(3)/L^2.
